newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: End draws nears for Power NZ takeover battle.
newsitem.headline: End draws nears for Power NZ takeover battle.

text.p: The end is drawing near for the battle for control of Power New Zealand Ltd after two-and- a-half years of protracted haggling over the country's biggest listed power distributor, analysts said on Friday.
The protagonists -- unlisted Mercury Energy and Kansas-based UtiliCorp United Inc -- finally got together this week in a deal to share control through a 50/50 joint venture.

The pair together own 64 percent of Power NZ and are proposing to buy out minority shareholders for NZ$6.0 (US$4.15) a share after lodging an application with the New Zealand Commerce Commission to seek 100 percent.
Bancorp Advisory Services has been commissioned by the Power NZ board to carry out an independent appraisal on the offer.
If the partners succeed,the NZSE-40 Capital Index company faces possible delisting after a brief but controversial presence on the New Zealand Stock Exchange boards.
Power NZ debuted in December 1994 having made the transition from a local authority-style power board to a company.
No sooner had it listed than a battle for control began.
Power NZ had enlisted UtiliCorp as a "cornerstone" shareholder, enabling it to share technology and giving it a measure of protection against predators.

Aucklanders, many of them first-time shareholders thanks to a large scale share allocation to customers, watched in astonishment when Mercury entered the fray virtually on day one, with bids and counterbids driving offers as high as NZ$10 per share against its listing price of just NZ$3.40.
Capital appreciation aside, the company has paid out big dividends -- almost enough to cover Mercury's holding costs.
Unlisted Mercury is New Zealand's largest power supplier with 18.0 percent market share against Power NZ's 13.0 percent.

Lying uncomfortably between Power NZ's Waitemata network to the north and its Valley Power assets in the south, Mercury argued it could achieve substantial benefits from a merger with Waitemata and from the divestment of Valley Power.
Power NZ and UtiliCorp countered by saying modern distribution technology made such geographical issues irrelevant.
As if to prove that point, Power NZ launched a bid for Wellington's EnergyDirect Ltd at the other end of the North Island. But that failed.
One result of this week's announcement will be that both Mercury and Power NZ will cooperate to capture cost savings.
However, the parties have several hurdles to clear first.
They first need sanction from the Overseas Investment Commission, which rarely turns down applications, and also the approval of the Commerce Commission.
Don Turkington, principal at Cavill White Securities, said a successful takeover by the joint venture may not be a foregone conclusion.

"People who wouldn't sell at eight dollars may be even less inclined to sell at six, so whether they can get to 90.0 percent in order to compulsorily acquire balance I don't know," he said. "It's always a negative thing for the market to have companies removed from the board but Power NZ was on for such a short time before it became part of a takeover attempt that it hasn't had a two-way market at all. It's been very illiquid."
One major positive development would be the removal of a barrier to Mercury's partial listing, scheduled for mid-1998, which would be the biggest float since Telecom.
Mercury on Friday announced a 25 percent increase in annual net profit to NZ$82.1 million.
